body:
I'm also not in favor of this proposal. It only begs for more features: flags read from a file before and others, flags read from a file during. It opens new questions: what happens when a flag is set from a file and from the command-line - should a user be warned because it's not necessarily visible, etc. etc.

But there's also a secondary effect, a meta-issue, if you will: Once it's possible to read from a flag file, applications will start using that feature (flag file for configurations, etc.). It's going to make those applications more complicated. It will lead to a proliferation of flags (hey, just consume the 100-line flag file!).

I think there's a fine balance between providing basic flag support (which is what we have now), and opening the door to "flags processing". Go apps that need the latter might want to use a custom solution or external package. Most Go apps won't need such a mechanism and shouldn't be encouraged to go in that direction.

As a former Googler, @tlimoncelli, you know what "flag proliferation" means at Google scale... :-) I don't think we want to go there.

cc: @robpike
